content.story_intro: Apache Struts CVE-2017-5638. Patch disponible 2 meses antes. No aplicado.

steps.title: Vulnerability: Apache Struts
steps.content: 6 Marzo 2017: Apache Struts CVE-2017-5638 publicado (CVSS 10.0). RCE sin autenticación. Equifax usaba Struts en dispute portal. Patch disponible MISMO DÍA.
steps.insight: CVSS 10.0 = máxima severidad. Patch disponible. Equifax tenía 2 MESES para parchear antes del breach.

steps.title: Risk Management Failure
steps.content: Equifax vulnerability management process falló. Scanner detectó Struts vulnerable PERO no escaló a patch. 2 meses sin acción. 13 Mayo: Attackers explotaron.
steps.insight: Tener scanner ≠ estar seguro. Need: Detection → Prioritization → Patch → Verification. Full lifecycle.

steps.title: Exfiltration: 147M Records
steps.content: Attackers pivotaron de dispute portal a databases. 147M records: SSN, DOB, addresses, driver licenses. 76 días sin detectar. No segmentación de red.
steps.insight: RCE → Pivot → Exfiltration. Defense in depth ausente. Database no debería ser accesible desde web server.

steps.title: Detection Failure
steps.content: SSL inspection certificate expiró. Equifax NO podía monitorear outbound traffic cifrado. Exfiltración invisible por 76 días. Monitoring gaps = blind spots.
steps.insight: Expired certs = monitoring down. No alerting on monitoring failure = compounding error.

steps.title: Aftermath: $700M Settlement
steps.content: $700M settlement con FTC. CEO Richard Smith renunció. CIO/CSO despedidos. Class action lawsuits. Congressional testimony. Reputational damage permanente.
steps.insight: Costo de no parchear vulnerabilidad conocida: $700M+ en multas, executive careers ended, trust destroyed.

steps.title: Lessons: Risk Management
steps.content: GAO report: 1) Patch management process broken. 2) Asset inventory incomplete (no sabían todos Struts instances). 3) Segmentation ausente. 4) Monitoring gaps. 5) Expired certificates.
steps.insight: Risk management is foundational. Technical debt kills. Proper processes > heroic firefighting.

back.definition: Risk es función de probabilidad de ocurrencia Y magnitud de daño. Alto likelihood + bajo impact puede ser < bajo likelihood + catastrophic impact.
back.example: Equifax: High likelihood (Struts vuln public, actively exploited). High impact (147M records). Result: Critical risk. Should have been priority 1 patch.

back.definition: Appetite: Cuánto risk org willing to take para achieve objectives. Tolerance: Max deviation acceptable. Board-level decisions.
back.example: Startup: High risk appetite (move fast). Bank: Low risk appetite (regulatory). Equifax tolerance: Clearly exceeded when patch delayed 2 months.

back.definition: 1) Avoid: Don't do risky activity. 2) Mitigate: Implement controls. 3) Transfer: Insurance, outsource. 4) Accept: Acknowledge, document decision.
back.example: Equifax should: Mitigate (patch immediately). Transfer (cyber insurance). Actually did: Accept (implicitly, by inaction). Wrong choice.

back.definition: Can't protect what you don't know exists. Comprehensive inventory: hardware, software, data, cloud resources. Equifax problem: Incomplete inventory.
back.example: CMDB (Configuration Management Database). Asset tagging. Discovery scans. Equifax: Didn't know all Struts instances = couldn't patch all.

unlock_content.title: Asset Discovery
points: Network scanning: Nmap, Nessus, Qualys
Agent-based: Deploy agents on endpoints for inventory
Cloud discovery: AWS Config, Azure Resource Graph
Application discovery: Dependency mapping, SBOM (Software Bill of Materials)
Equifax gap: Incomplete inventory = missed Struts instances
Update frequency: Continuous or weekly minimum
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Shadow IT is real. Developers deploy without approval. Continuous discovery catches this.

unlock_content.title: Scanning Strategy
points: Authenticated scans: Better accuracy (can see installed patches)
Unauthenticated scans: Attacker perspective
Frequency: Weekly for general, daily for critical assets
Scan types: Network, web app (DAST), code (SAST), containers
Equifax: Had scanners but results not acted upon
False positives: Validate findings before panic
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Scanner detected Equifax vulnerability. Problem was downstream: no action taken.

unlock_content.title: Prioritization Factors
points: CVSS score: Baseline (10.0 = critical)
Exploitability: Is exploit public? Actively exploited?
Asset criticality: Internet-facing? Crown jewels?
Compensating controls: Firewall, WAF mitigating?
Vendor priority: Microsoft Patch Tuesday severity
Equifax: CVSS 10.0 + public exploit + internet-facing = P0
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Not all CVEs equal. CVSS 10.0 internet-facing > CVSS 9.0 internal asset.

unlock_content.title: Patch Management
points: Testing: Patch in dev/staging before production
Change control: Approval process, rollback plan
Maintenance windows: Schedule with stakeholders
Emergency patching: Expedited process for critical (Equifax needed this)
Verification: Re-scan post-patch to confirm
Documentation: What patched, when, by whom
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Equifax had 2 months. Emergency patch should have happened in 48 hours for CVSS 10.0.

unlock_content.title: VM Metrics
points: Mean Time To Patch (MTTP): Goal <30 days standard, <7 days critical
Vulnerability debt: Total open vulnerabilities by severity
SLA compliance: % patched within policy timeframe
Repeat vulnerabilities: Same CVE reappearing = systemic issue
Equifax metric: MTTP for critical = 60+ days. Unacceptable.
Executive dashboard: Trend over time, risk exposure
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Good VM program: MTTP critical <7 days. Equifax: 60+ days. Order of magnitude off.

back.definition: General Data Protection Regulation. EU citizen data protection. Rights: Access, erasure, portability. 72-hour breach notification. Fines up to 4% global revenue.
back.example: Equifax: If EU citizens affected, GDPR violation. British Airways: £183M fine. Marriott: £99M. Consent, data minimization, privacy by design mandatory.

back.definition: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard. 12 requirements: Firewall, encryption, access control, monitoring, testing. Quarterly ASV scans, annual audit.
back.example: Target breach: PCI violation. Fines from card brands + loss of ability to process cards. SAQ (Self-Assessment Questionnaire) for small merchants.

back.definition: Health Insurance Portability & Accountability Act. PHI (Protected Health Information) security. Administrative, physical, technical safeguards. Breach notification 60 days.
back.example: Healthcare breaches avg $10M cost. HHS Wall of Shame: Public breach list. Must report 500+ affected individuals. Equifax: Medical records included.

back.definition: Sarbanes-Oxley Act. Public company financial reporting integrity. IT controls over financial systems. Segregation of duties, audit trails, change management.
back.example: Section 404: Internal control assessment. IT general controls (ITGC): Access, change, operations. Equifax: Public company, SOX applicable.

content.question: Equifax breach: ¿Cuál fue el PRIMARY risk management failure?

options.feedback: Incorrecto. Equifax SÍ tenía scanner. Scanner detectó la vulnerabilidad Struts. Problem was downstream.

options.text: Vulnerability scanning → Risk prioritization → Remediation process BROKE. Scanner detected, pero no action.
options.feedback: CORRECTO! Scanner funcionó: Detectó CVE-2017-5638. Pero process breakdown: 1) Results no escalados properly. 2) CVSS 10.0 no triggered emergency patch. 3) No verification que patch aplicado. 4) Incomplete asset inventory = missed some Struts. 5) Process de patch management lento (60+ days). Full lifecycle falló. Technology worked, process failed. Risk management is about PROCESS, not just tools.
Incorrecto. CVE-2017-5638 publicado 6 Marzo. Patch disponible MISMO DÍA. Equifax breached 13 Mayo = 2+ meses DESPUÉS. Not zero-day.
Parcialmente correcto. Cert expiration causó monitoring gap (detection failure). Pero PRIMARY failure: No parchar vulnerabilidad conocida por 2 meses. Cert issue compounded problema.
